summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan, opposing Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team's requests. The government argues against disclosing witness names 11 months before trial and against court intervention in her Bureau of Prisons (BOP) confinement conditions at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC). It details the government's timely discovery production and the BOP's accommodations for Maxwell's case preparation.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330), accused of crimes related to Jeffrey Epstein. Her defense counsel is requesting early witness disclosure and challenging her jail conditions.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The government's letter is addressed to her, opposing the defense's motions.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The Acting U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York who signed and submitted this opposition letter on behalf of the government.

connections.description: Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case. This document is the government's opposition to motions filed by Maxwell's defense before Judge Nathan.
Strauss, as Acting U.S. Attorney, is leading the prosecution against Maxwell. This letter is her office's formal opposition to the defense's requests.

events.title: Protective Order Docketed
events.description: The protective order governing discovery in the Maxwell case was posted to the court docket, enabling the start of discovery production.

events.title: Initial Discovery Production
events.description: The government produced an initial discovery batch of over 12,000 pages to the defense.

events.title: Second Discovery Production
events.description: The government made a second discovery production totaling over 150,000 pages, primarily financial records.

events.title: Maxwell Receives Discovery at MDC
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell received her copy of the first discovery production at the Metropolitan Detention Center.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Date
events.description: The trial for United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell is scheduled for July 2021, approximately 11 months from the date of this letter.

locations: Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The government had produced over 165,000 pages of discovery to Ghislaine Maxwell's defense within two weeks of the protective order being entered.
The government strongly opposed disclosing the names of victim-witnesses 11 months before trial, citing victim privacy and lack of legal precedent.
The Bureau of Prisons (BOP) was providing Maxwell extended access to discovery materials from 7:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. daily at the MDC.
The government expressed concern that Maxwell's defense counsel had referenced sealed discovery materials from the criminal case in a public civil court filing.
The defense's request for court intervention in Maxwell's jail conditions was deemed moot by the government, as the BOP had already implemented a modified plan for her discovery access.
